thread.title: Can tiny drones mimic the role of bees?
thread.title_full: Can tiny drones mimic the role of bees?

author: Imogen Brennan
title: Can tiny drones mimic the role of bees?

organizations.name: national institute of advanced industrial science and technology

text:
Map: Japan 
Japanese scientists are investigating whether tiny drones can deliver pollen to flowers, mimicking the role of bees, as the insect faces increasing threats from viruses and pesticides around the world. 
The drones are capable of flying between lily flowers, collecting and dispersing pollen just as a bee would. 
While the tiny drones are impressive, the scientists from Japan's National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology say the innovation is in the special gel covering them. 
Dr Eijiro Miyako experimented to see if ionic liquid gel could pick up pollen-like material from one flower, and then deposit it to a second flower. 
In a paper published in the journal Chem, the team said their research was successful, and demonstrated robot pollinators could counter the problems caused by declining honeybee populations. 
They said the robotic pollinators could be trained to learn pollination paths by using global positioning systems and artificial intelligence. 
Katja Hogendoorn, a postdoctoral research associate at the University of Adelaide and an expert in crop pollination, said the invention was a promising development. 
"It is an intriguing idea of course, it's not new as an idea, it's a start — they've achieved it with a very big flower, mind you," she said. 
"But we have a long way to go when you consider orchards with numerous flowers stretching for kilometres. 
"In an orchard, what you would need is automated recognition of the flowers, so the robot really needs to know where to go first to get the pollen and then where to go to deliver it, which bees know automatically because they're after food." Scepticism around commercial applications Photo: An artificial pollinator device carrying a gel invented by Japanese scientists to collect and disperse pollen, mimicking the role of bees. (AIST: Eijiro Miyak) 
Dr Hogendoorn said there was a dire need for sustainable solutions. 
"If the bees are struggling, how can we make them survive while still being productive in agriculture?" she said. 
But Australian Honey Bee Industry Council executive director Trevor Weatherhead is sceptical about whether robot pollinators can be used at a commercial scale. 
"This little machine will certainly pollinate, but how many would you need for, say, 1,000 acres?," he said. Audio: Listen to Imogen Brennan's full story (The World Today) 
"The other thing, for instance, you take macadamias or avocados where the flowers are on trees, the bees actually have to get in amongst the leaves to do the pollination. 
"You have your pumpkins and watermelons where the flowers are in under the leaves themselves, and the bees sort of fly in under — I'm not sure how the robots would be able to get in and out." 
He said it is not the first time his industry has faced similar problems. 
"There are certainly problems and we're encountering them all the time," Mr Weatherhead said. 
"For instance, you take your varroa mite, it's out there [but] Australia doesn't have it and we don't want it. 
"When it comes here it will certainly have an effect, but beekeepers finally adapt to it with pesticides — we sort of keep pushing and pushing for the safe application of pesticides."
